commit_message:
Enables MySQL Cluster Support for Cinder

Defines the specifications for implementing MySQL Cluster support
for Cinder.

Change-Id: Ib79d39cd4dbd029ad096ef625de0af5bf4ca9271
Depends-On: I9f1fd2a87fdf75332de2339d3ff4f08ce9220dcf
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder-specs refs/changes/98/432498/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== MySQL Cluster Support ========================================== Launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/mysql-cluster-support OpenStack today uses the standard MySQL DB with the InnoDB engine as the back-bone of the core services. InnoDB is an active/passive database with limited high-availability and scale-out capabilities. MySQL Cluster is a variant of the MySQL Database that uses the NDB (Network Database) engine. This database is ideal for massive scale-out and has been used in the telecommunication industry extensively over the years. Key Benefits for MySQL Cluster: - 99.999% Availability - Shared Nothing Architecture, no points of failure - Synchronous Replication - Auto Sharding of Data - Auto Fail-over - Self-Healing - Max. of 255 nodes in cluster (48 data nodes, other nodes SQL/API) - SQL and API nodes scale-out horizontally via load balancing Key Benefits for OpenStack: - Highly-Available DB back-end - Massively scalible DB back-end - Reduced operational impact of planned or unplanned DB maintenance. - Reduced complexity compared to InnoDB clustering. - No shared storage or 3rd party clustering software required. Links to information on MySQL Cluster: Documentation: https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/mysql-cluster.html MySQL Cluster Overview: https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/mysql-cluster-overview.html Limitations of MySQL Cluster: https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/mysql-cluster-limitations.html Problem description =================== The following challenges exist for supporting MySQL Cluster today: - Table row length limited to 14k in NDB vs 65k in InnoDB - Hardcoding of SQL statements such as "mysql_engine=InnoDB" - Strict adherence to ordering of SQL operations for foreign keys, constraints, and indexes. - No support for Savepoints - No support for Nested transactions Use Cases ========= - Operator wants a MySQL DB with 99.999% uptime availability and massive scale-out capabilities. - Operator wants a multi-master MySQL DB that allows for rolling-upgrades of MySQL software and/or infrastructure without impacting service availability. - In either case, the operator will have to configure MySQL Cluster DB and configure the mysql_storage_engine setting to NDBCLUSTER in the cinder.conf file for this enhancement to work. Otherwise, this enhancement will default to InnoDB with no change in behavior. Proposed change =============== - Enhance oslo.db to add the configuration setting of mysql_storage_engine so that operators can select either InnoDB or NDBCLUSTER to enable the correct logic in the SQL Alchemy and Alembic migration scripts. The plan is to target the database section of the cfg.CONF.database namespace for this option to make it available across all OpenStack services. - Patch SQL Alchemy and Alembic database migration scripts to have logic to modify table schemas and behavior to fit within the constraints of MySQL Cluster (NDB). For example, change the column size 255 char strings to something smaller for columns that only hold the state of a service component that consumes less than 10 or 20 characters. Or converting large string columns (i.e. over 1024 chars.) to TEXT to reduce the size of the row length. - Patch SQL Alchemy and Alembic database migration scripts to properly handle the ordering of operations against foreign keys, constraints, and indexes. - Patch service components to transparently work with any MySQL Cluster (NDB) changes. This includes database related api.py and model.py files for handling schema modifications or hard-coded use cases or features (savepoints and nested). These changes will be validated and tested to ensure that: - Zero impact to functionality of APIs, CLIs, and service processes. - Zero impact on operators using MySQL InnoDB. - Minimal operator overhead for enabling NDB functionality. Alternatives ------------ Through the design, architecture, and implementation of these changes the following alternative approaches are being considered: - Creating a new NDB dialect for SQL Alchemy to enable the use of in-line substitutions of column definitions based on dialect. This could potentially reduce IF/THEN logic blocks. - Reducing the column sizes across service databases where appropriate and sensible. Doing this would impact both InnoDB and NDB use cases but reduce the amount of overhead in maintaining conditional logic. This could lead to better efficiency in not only the patches, but in the database structures. Some services like Cinder, Nova, and Neutron have already run into the 65k limit in InnoDB which has forced some columns to migrate to separate tables. Data model impact ----------------- When an operator configures Cinder to use MySQL Cluster (NDB), this will enable logic in the SQL Alchemy scripts to adjust the setting of the mysql_engine to NDBCLUSTER and will make the following data model changes to the volumes table: - availability_zone -> TinyText - mountpoint -> TinyText - attach_time -> TinyText - display_description -> TinyText This logic will be implemented in the 001_cinder_init.py and the models.py files respectively. This will allow these columns to fit within NDB row limit of 14k characters. It will have zero affect on the default MySQL InnoDB database schema. REST API impact --------------- None. Security impact --------------- None. Notifications impact -------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ None. Other deployer impact --------------------- Deployers will see the "mysql_storage_engine" setting in the database section of the cinder.conf file, which gets pulled-in from the oslo.db namespace. By default, this will be set to "InnoDB", even if the setting is not uncommented. If the deployer wishes to use MySQL Cluster, they will have to set this to "NDBCLUSTER" for the feature to be enabled. Developer impact ---------------- Future data model changes will have to take into account columns that exceed the 14k row limit in NDB and implement one of the following: - IF/THEN logic to change the column type when using MySQL Cluster. - Modify the column type globally for InnoDB and NDB. - Shift the column to another table. Additionally, any table modifications that are done that do not follow the proper dropping and adding of foreign keys, constraints, and indexes will need to add the required steps to follow the strict behavior of MySQL Cluster. This is already done with many of the SQL Alchemy upgrades already, so it is not a new thing. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Octave Orgeron (octave.orgeron@oracle.com) Other contributors: TBD Work Items ---------- - Implement the changes the SQL Alchemy scripts and the models.py file. Dependencies ============ #1564110 oslo.db needs a method for selecting mysql storage engine Depends-On: I9f1fd2a87fdf75332de2339d3ff4f08ce9220dcf Testing ======= MySQL Cluster will be made avialable via the OpenStack CI or an Oracle based 3rd party CI. A temptest test will need to be created that will enable this feature and run through the Cinder API functional tests and CLI tests. Documentation Impact ==================== Documentation will need to be added to the database configuration section for the cinder.conf to explain the feature and how to enable it. References ========== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/oslo.db/+spec/mysql-cluster-support

commit_message:
Auto-fencing to support HA A/A

This spec outlines work needed for volume nodes to auto-fence themselves
when they lose connection to the DB to prevent cleanup procedure to
access the same resources while the node keeps working on it.

This is one of the aspects that are needed to support Active/Active in
cinder.

Implements: blueprint cinder-volume-active-active-support
Change-Id: I7da600824441341eed8cc13a48f35e50821d8156
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder-specs refs/changes/76/237076/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================================================= Cinder Volume Active/Active support - Prevent Data Corruption ============================================================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/cinder-volume-active-active-support Right now cinder-volume service can run only in Active/Passive HA fashion. One of the reasons for this is that a node will not stop processing or receiving requests for as long as he is running, regardless of the connection to the DB, Message Broker and Storage Backend. This is fine when only Active/Passive configurations are allowed, but when we have multiple nodes that can access the same resources on the same Storage Backend and we have the scheduler doing cleanups as well- as `HA A/A Cleanup specs`_ explains- this is not right. This spec introduces a new auto-fencing mechanism to prevent multiple nodes from accessing the same resources on the same Storage Backend simultaneously unintentionally. Problem description =================== Since we can have multiple Volume Nodes accessing the same Storage Backend we have to prevent more than one node accessing the same resource on the backend unintentionally. That is the case when a node loses connection to the DB and can no longer report heartbeats and the scheduler starts with the cleanup. We have to prevent both the node doing the cleanup and the node that lost DB connection from accessing the same resource. We also want to prevent nodes that have lost connection to the DB from getting new jobs, as they will always fail and they could be getting the cleanup jobs from their own jobs. Use Cases ========= Operators that have hard requirements, SLA or other reasons, to have their cloud operational at all times or have higher throughput requirements will want to have the possibility to configure their deployments with an Active/Active configuration and be sure that there is no data corruption caused by undesired concurrent access to a resource. Proposed change =============== The idea is for Volume nodes to be able to auto-fence themselves to prevent data corruption. This new auto-fencing mechanism will require two changes, one that prevents the node from getting new jobs and another that stops current jobs execution. Preventing a node from getting new jobs will be handled in Service's ``report_state`` method by calling Oslo Messaging Handler's ``stop`` method when we have a problem on the manager (``is_working`` returns False) or when we have any kind of exception doing the DB heartbeat. We should also stop all ongoing jobs that are accessing resources on the Storage Backend, for this we'll need to add a ``kill_all`` method in the different Executors of ``futures`` module and in Oslo messaging Executors, as we don't currently have a way to kill jobs. When DB connection is restored and we start sending heartbeats we should do resource cleanup -as explained in `HA A/A Cleanup specs`_- and ``start`` the Message Handler. We should increase the frequency of heartbeats to every second once a heartbeat fails and until one succeeds. If we do this we could postpone stopping current jobs for a number of tries. For example 1/6th of ``periodic_interval``. In the future we could add additional auto-fencing cases, for example when we lose connection to the Storage Backend or if we are using a DLM when we lose connection to it. In an ideal world we would reschedule on other nodes all jobs that have not been started -if our connection to the Message Broker is not lost-, but this is quite far-fetched, since we would need to retrieve jobs from ``_delayed_work`` queue in ``futures`` executor. Alternatives ------------ We could just abruptly exit the running program and let an external cluster manager fix things. Or we could create our own monitor that will monitor when DB connection is lost and kills Cinder -or waits for Cinder to exit because of DB connection issue- and waits for the connection to be restored before restarting the service. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Gorka Eguileor (geguileo) Other contributors: Anyone is welcome to help Work Items ---------- - Add ``kill_all`` method to ``futures`` executors that stops all ongoing threads/greenthreads and clears queued jobs. - Add ``kill_all`` method to Oslo Messaging Executors, or at least add an optional force argument that defaults to False to current ``stop`` method so it can call ``kill_all`` method from ``futures``. - Add calls to ``stop`` and ``kill_all`` in Service's ``report_state`` method. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unittests for new DB connection lost and recovering cases. Documentation Impact ==================== Depending on final solution -proposed versus alternatives- this new behavior may need documenting. References ========== General Description for HA A/A: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/232599/ Job Distribution for HA A/A: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/232595/ .. _HA A/A Cleanup specs: https://review.openstack.org/236977

Change-Id: Idca5fefbaf3d229a6f91c1fc0a5c7df4d8fa5f2c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder-specs refs/changes/18/559718/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ===================================== Integrate placement service in cinder ===================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/placeholder-for-link This blueprint proposes to integrate Nova's placement service in cinder to support scheduler HA. Problem description =================== TBD Use Cases ========= TBD Proposed change =============== 1. Provider & Inventory & Trait model ------------------------------------- In order to integrate Placement server into Cinder, the basic part is to design the Provider and Inventory based on our backend or pool state. This figure below is a status reported by one of our backend drivers. .. code-block:: javascript { "filter_function": "", "goodness_function": "", "shared_targets": false, "volume_backend_name": "lvmdriver-1", "driver_version": "3.0.0", "sparse_copy_volume": true, "pools": [ { "pool_name": "lvmdriver-1", "filter_function": "", "goodness_function": "", "multiattach": true, "total_volumes": "1 1", "provisioned_capacity_gb": 10.0, "allocated_capacity_gb": 10, "thin_provisioning_support": true, "free_capacity_gb": 9.32, "location_info": "LVMVolumeDriver:hostname:lvmgroup:thin:0", "total_capacity_gb": 9.51, "thick_provisioning_support": false, "reserved_percentage": 0, "QoS_support": false, "max_over_subscription_ratio": "20.0", "backend_state": "up" } ], "vendor_name": "Open Source", "storage_protocol": "iSCSI" } And we can classify them into three different parts: 1. Attributes suitable for Inventory, they are ``provisioned_capacity_gb``, ``free_capacity_gb``, ``total_capacity_gb``, ``reserved_percentage``, etc. 2. Attributes suitable for Traits. Traits are qualitative characteristics of resource providers and ``multiattach``, ``thin_provisioning_support``, ``thick_provisioning_support``, ``sparse_copy_volume``, are all valid candidates. 3. Attributes not suitable for Placement, they are additional attributes which used to describe backend, such as ``pool_name``, ``location_info``, ``filter_function``, ``goodness_function`` and etc. Considering our relationship between volume service, volume backend and storage pool, we may have the Provider and Inventory model as below:: +-------------------+ | Provider: hostname| +-------------------+ ^ | ---------------------------------------- ^ ^ |(Parent Provider) |(Parent Provider) +-----------------------------+ +-----------------------------+ | Provider: hostname@backend-1| | Provider: hostname@backend-2| +-----------------------------+ +-----------------------------+ ^ ^ | (Parent Provider) |(Other backend Provider) ------------------------------------------ | | +-----------------------------------+ +-----------------------------------+ | Provider: hostname@backend-1#pool1| | Provider: hostname@backend-1#pool1| +-----------------------------------+ +-----------------------------------+ ^ | ------------------------------ |(RC:THICK_DISK_MIB) |(RC:THIN_DISK_MIB) +--------------------------+ +--------------------------+ |Inventory(if pool support)| |Inventory(if pool support)| +--------------------------+ +--------------------------+ **NOTE**: 1. Inventory ``THICK_DISK_MIB`` and ``THIN_DISK_MIB`` will be added only when backend announces that is supported via ``thin_provisioning_support`` and ``thick_provisioning_support``. 2. GiB is the first choice, but considering Placement doesn't support float while our backend driver will report capacity within float, we can use MiB instead. There are five key attributes in Inventory, considering the concepts may be different among Cinder and Placement, We have to convert them before updating to Placement. 1. For **THICK** pool 1. ``allocation_ratio``: 1.0 2. ``max_unit``: equal to ``total`` in default 3. ``min_unit``: 1024 4. ``reserved``: Floor(``total_capacity_gb`` * Float(``reserved_percentage``/100))*1024 5. ``step_size``: 1024 in default 6. ``total``: Floor(``provisioned_capacity_gb(allocated_capacity_gb)`` + ``free_capacity_gb``)*1024 2. For **THIN** pool 1. ``allocation_ratio``: ``max_over_subscription_ratio``, also it's can be calculated when ``max_over_subscription_ratio`` configured ``auto``. 2. ``max_unit``: equal to ``total`` in default 3. ``min_unit``: 1024 4. ``reserved``: Floor(``total_capacity_gb`` * Float(``reserved_percentage``/100))*1024 5. ``step_size``: 1024 in default 6. ``total``: Floor((``provisioned_capacity_gb(allocated_capacity_gb)``/``allocation_ratio``) + ``free_capacity_gb``)*1024 We use calculated value here for ``total`` attribute in order to represent pool capacity state more correctly. Based on Placement's algorithm, we will finally have this formula below to decide whether provider is valid for request:: => request_capacity <= ((free_capacity+provisioned_capacity/ratio)-reserved)*ratio - sum(allocations) => request_capacity <= (free_capacity -reserved)*ratio And this is what we already have in our capacity filter. **Question**: How to support the case when driver reports the ``total_capacity_gb`` is ``infinite`` or ``unknown`` rather than digital number? Regarding traits, we would extract our common capabilities to traits when reporting: 1. ``CUSTOM_SPARCE_COPY``: corresponding to ``sparse_copy_volume`` 2. ``CUSTOM_QOS``: corresponding to ``QoS_support`` 3. ``CUSTOM_MULTIATTACH``: corresponding to ``multiattach`` 4. ``CUSTOM_PROTOCOL_ISCSI``: corresponding to ``storage_protocol=iSCSI`` 5. ``CUSTOM_PROTOCOL_DRBD``: corresponding to ``storage_protocol=DRBD`` 6. Other storage custom protocol traits 2. Update in volume service --------------------------- 1. New Class ``ProviderTree`` will be added to represent service's backend provider tree and cache Placement info. 2. New Class ``ReportClient`` will be added which acts as a Placement proxy to create/delete new allocations, get candidates, update inventories and etc. 3. New Class ``ResourceReport`` will be added which is responsible for caching backend states, claiming resources and select candidates for scheduler and update inventories and traits via ``ReportClient`` if necessary. 4. Volume service will still report backend state to scheduler as before since scheduler plugins will use the additional attributes, such as ``goodness_function``. 5. Volume service will now report backend state to Placement via ``ResourceReport`` during periodic task. 6. Volume service will now ask driver to report backend state and then update the Inventory via ``ResourceReport`` when resource is created\deleted\extended at the backend as well. 7. Volume service will now delete corresponding allocation when resource is successfully deleted as well as before sending request to scheduler for rescheduling. 3. Update in scheduler service ------------------------------ 1. Scheduler will now ask Placement for provider (backend) candidates before requiring plugins to filter and weigh backends. 2. Scheduler will now create allocations right after backend is chosen. 3. ``consume_from_volume`` will be removed since all capacity related data has been moved to Placement. Alternatives ------------ TBD Data model impact ----------------- TBD REST API impact --------------- TBD Cinder-client impact -------------------- TBD Security impact --------------- TBD Notifications impact -------------------- TBD Other end user impact --------------------- TBD Performance Impact ------------------ TBD Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- TBD Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: tommylikehu(tommylikehu@gmail.com) Work Items ---------- TBD Dependencies ============ TBD Testing ======= TBD Documentation Impact ==================== TBD References ========== None

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-10-03 15:40:17.000000000', 'files': ['.zuul.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs/commit/32a202874cdd74639ec84602cfd9e33240a07e26', 'message': 'Always run py27 test

The py27 test ensures that all specs are following a specific format.
The default py27 tests have an irrelevant-files list that ignores
running if especially only .rst files get updated. Override the
irrelevant files list so that it runs for nearly all changes,
only skip for release-notes (even if they do not exist here).

Change-Id: Iffb6345ddf490820ca7495f0e4a0e722acfba898

commit_message:
Always run py27 test

The py27 test ensures that all specs are following a specific format.
The default py27 tests have an irrelevant-files list that ignores
running if especially only .rst files get updated. Override the
irrelevant files list so that it runs for nearly all changes,
only skip for release-notes (even if they do not exist here).

Change-Id: Iffb6345ddf490820ca7495f0e4a0e722acfba898

commit_message:
Proposal to count resources to check quota in API

Proposal to count resources to check quota in API.

Change-Id: I659e29cdf49d1631aa0fa6983639efb6742e336e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder-specs refs/changes/62/496562/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ====================================== Count resources to check quota in API ====================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/lol-where-is-the-spec We propose a new approach of counting consumed resources and checking the count against the quota limits in the API instead of the current reserve/commit model where a reservation record is created, quota usage records are created and marked as "in_use" when they are committed, and the reservation record deleted. Since Nova has already introduced this feature during Pike `[1]`_, we will take the same approach as Nova did. Problem description =================== The current quota design consists of reservations and commits/rollbacks. A simplified explanation of how it works during a create is: "reserve" creates a reservation record and a usage record indicating resources are "reserved." "Commit" updates the usage record to modify the "reserved" field, the "in use" field, and deletes the reservation record. "Rollback" updates the usage record to modify the "reserved" field and deletes the reservation record. For volume create, resources are first reserved in the API when a request is received and then the reservation is later committed in cinder volume service when the volume is created. We could have several issues for our current quota usage/reservation system: 1. Cinder use ``FOR UPDATE`` to lock the quota usage records which means it will have a negative performance impact when batch requests on same project and same resource are handled. 2. In order to keep the correctness of the resource usage, we add lot of codes which can't be easily maintained now or future to record and refresh the quota usage. 3. There is a possibility that we could have multiplies quota usage records for the identical resource `[2]`_. 4. We could have quota_usage record whose resource name is longer than 255 `[3]`_. Use Cases ========= The main use case of this change is to make cinder more adaptive for large deployment and more efficient for batch operations. Proposed change =============== 1. Consumed resources will be counted to check quota instead of the current reserve/commit/rollback model. * "Reserve," "commit," and "rollback" calls will be removed everywhere. Quota checks will instead consist of reading the quota limits from the API database and comparing the limit with the resource count. * "Reserve" calls will be replaced with something like "check_resource_count" which will query the databases for consumed resources, count them, and raise OverQuota if quota limits for the project can't accomodate the request. 2. New configuration option ``recheck_quota`` will be introduced to prevent exceeded quota. The initial quota check is done before resources are created, so if multiple parallel requests arrive at the same time, all could pass the quota check and create resources, potentially exceeding quota. When ``recheck_quota`` is True, quota will be checked a second time after resources have been created and if the resource is over quota, it will be deleted and OverQuota will be raised, usually resulting in a 403 response to the REST API user. This makes it impossible for a user to exceed their quota with the caveat that it will, however, be possible for a REST API user to be rejected with a 403 response in the event of a collision close to reaching their quota limit, even if the user has enough quota available when they made the request. 3. Update resource type for existing quota resource. Here is an explanation of our current resource types. * **ReservableResource**: Can be used with reservations, resources are stored in the DB. * **AbsoluteResource**: Number of resources are not stored in the DB. * **CountableResource**: Subclass of AbsoluteResource except resources are stored in the DB. Has a counting function that will be called to determine the current counts of the resource. Not intended to count by project ID. With the new approach, it seems like ReservableResources should be changed to CountableResources with a count function provided for each: * volumes(CountableResource) * per_volume_gigabytes(AbsoluteResource) * snapshots(CountableResource) * gigabytes(CountableResource) * backups(CountableResource) * backup_gigabytes(CountableResource) * groups(CountableResource) * consistencygroups(CountableResource) Take ``volume`` resource for instance, we need to add a count function which will count volume resource for one specific project or volume type:: def _volume_count(context, project_id, volume_type_id=None): """Get the counts of volumes in the database. :returns: A dict containing the project scoped counts and volume type scoped counts if volume type is specified. For example: .. code-block:: json {'project': {'volumes': <count across project>}, 'volume_type': {'volumes': <count across type>}} Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- We would not use the reservations and quota_usages tables start from this change and mark them as deprecated, and during next cycle these two will be dropped from the API database. REST API impact --------------- With this modification we could have a slight API impact on ``quota-usage``, the ``reserved`` attribute will be removed from API response. Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ Performance will be adversely affected in the case of counting resources twice (before and after the creation of resource). Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- Cinder developers will no longer call quota "reserve," "commit," or "rollback." Instead, they will call quota "check_resource_count" or similar when adding a new API which will consume quota. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: * TommyLike(tommylikehu@gmail.com) Work Items ---------- None Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= New unit tests will be added to cover the new resource counting scenarios. For the most part, this work should be transparent to end-users, so the existing suite of unit, functional, and integration tests should suffice for testing what is proposed. Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== 1. _`[1]`: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/cells-count-resources-to-check-quota-in-api 2. _`[2]`: https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1484343 3. _`[3]`: https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1608849

commit_message:
Support restore backup to volumes simultaneously

This spec proposes supporting restore backup to
different volumes simultaneously.

Change-Id: I7467e9526f9be54ae79d6a3306d4a08bf2ec6cc4
Partial-Implements: bp support-simultaneously-restore-backups
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder-specs refs/changes/41/524441/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================================ Support restore backup to volumes simultaneously ================================================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/support-simultaneously-restore-backups This blueprint proposes support restore one backup to different volumes simultaneously Problem description =================== Now when cinder restoring backup, other restoring requests on this backup will not be allowed until the task finished. This restriction is both inefficiency and unnecessary. Also we support create volume from image, snapshot, volume and backup, and backup is the only source which can not support creating multiple volumes with same source at the same time. Use Cases ========= Add the ability to restore (and create) multiple volumes with one specific backup simultaneously. Proposed change =============== Now we use ``restore_volume_id`` and backup status ``restoring`` to indicate whether backup is being used for restoring and which volume is being restoring to. To support multiple requests, the mentionable changes are below: 1. New foreign key ``restore_backup_id`` will be added in volume table ( back reference ``volumes`` in backup table). Once cinder starts or ends restoring action, this attribute will be set or unset. 2. When service starts, the backup cleanup operation will use ``volumes`` attribute to find out unfinished tasks and then update the corresponding volume's status. 3. ``restore_volume_id`` will not be used in the new process and will be dropped in the next cycle. 4. Conditional update will be used for updating backup's status: 1. When starts to restore, we will change the backup's status to 'restoring' only when original status is 'available' or 'restoring'. 2. When operation ends. we will change the backup's status to 'available' only if the backup's ``volumes`` are empty. Within this change, the backup object will always in 'restoring' status if multiple restoring requests on it are handled. Alternatives ------------ Keep ``available`` status when performing restore action is one of the alternative solutions. And the drawback of this is the driver need to prevent delete or any other destructive operation when performing restoring. Data model impact ----------------- New column will be added to the volume table +------------------------+--------------+------+-----+---------+ | Field | Type | Null | Key | Default | +------------------------+--------------+------+-----+---------+ | restore_backup_id | varchar(255) | YES | | NULL | +------------------------+--------------+------+-----+---------+ REST API impact --------------- None Cinder-client impact -------------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ There would be a performance impact on single restoring operation for some of the backup driver when multiple requests are handled. Discussion: Maybe we should add a config option to turn on/off this feature or set a maximal number how many volumes that a single backup can support restoring. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: tommylikehu(tommylikehu@gmail.com) Work Items ---------- * Support restoring backup simultaneously in cinder. * Update the unit and tempest to cover this change. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= * Add unit tests to cover this change. Documentation Impact ==================== Update API documentation. References ========== None

commit_message:
Remove pbr warnerrors in favor of sphinx check

This change removes the now unused "warnerrors" setting,
which is replaced by "warning-is-error" in sphinx
releases >= 1.5[0]. This also fixes any warnings
that came up when testing with the latest version
of sphinx:

- Redundant loading of todo extension
- Empty man_pages config value

Also updated the requirements for pbr and sphinx to the latest
version(s) in requirements.txt

With this change, any doc warnings will cause the build to fail
[0] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-March/113085.html

Change-Id: I1252b1912aa16240678c4b48af935d27131e9a0d

commit_message:
Remove race between sync_pools and _get_port_from_pool

This patch ensures that if there is an attempt to allocate a
port during the pod creation but the kuryr-controller has not yet
finished its sync_pool initialization, a ResourceNotReady exception
will be triggered and the port allocation attempt will be retried
later

Closes-Bug: 1800431
Change-Id: I92671523db6e9efc40ff248018c4e081fae750ed

subject: Support storing volume format info
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-18 12:39:52.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder-specs/commit/a730f1c54c1be4f5099ed8ab3adf690ea4422fa2', 'message': 'Support storing volume format info

Currently, there are several filesystem-based drivers in Cinder, such as
nfs, glusterfs, smbfs, etc. Multiple formats of volume other than "raw" can be
potentially supported in these drivers, such as qcow2, raw, vhd, etc.

This work aims to handle these files of various formats safely and
in a more robust manner.

blueprint add-support-store-volume-format-info

Co-Author: Trump Zhang <zhangleiqiang@huawei.com>

commit_message:
Support storing volume format info

Currently, there are several filesystem-based drivers in Cinder, such as
nfs, glusterfs, smbfs, etc. Multiple formats of volume other than "raw" can be
potentially supported in these drivers, such as qcow2, raw, vhd, etc.

This work aims to handle these files of various formats safely and
in a more robust manner.

blueprint add-support-store-volume-format-info

Co-Authored-By: Trump Zhang <zhangleiqiang@huawei.com>

Change-Id: I8b66af1d6b41f02a870d95cd9dddab83c34a9ded
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder-specs refs/changes/93/165393/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================================= Store volume format info in Cinder ================================================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/add-support-store-volume-format-info Problem description =================== Currently, there are several filesystem-based drivers in Cinder, such as nfs, glusterfs, smbfs, etc. Multiple formats of volume other than "raw" can be potentially supported in these drivers, such as qcow2, raw, nbd, etc. However, Cinder does not store the actual format of volume and supposes all volumes are "raw" format. It will have or already has several problems as follows: * For volume migration, the generic migration implementation in Cinder uses the "dd" command to copy "src" volume to "dest" volume. If the src volume is "qcow2" format, instance will not get the right data from volume after the dest volume attached to instance, because the info returned from Cinder states that the volume's format is "raw" other than "qcow2" * For volume backup, the backup driver also supposes that src volumes are "raw" format, other format will not be supported Proposed change =============== The "format" info should be added to "admin_metadata" of volumes, and enforce it on all operations, such as snapshot create, snapshot delete, clone, migrate and retype. The "format" will be only set / updated for filesystem-based drivers, other drivers will not contains this metadata and have a default "raw" format. When a snapshot is deleted, the format of the volume file may change from raw to qcow2. The metadata will be updated accordingly in this case. It does not presently ever change from qcow2 back to raw. When a snapshot is deleted by Cinder (volume is available): Since we know the format of the file being committed to, we know the format of the resulting base file and can update the metadata accordingly. When a snapshot is deleted by Nova (volume is in-use): Nova will return information about the file's resulting format via the update_snapshot_status API. When committing an intermediate snapshot, we can ignore this since it is not about the base volume file. (Or Nova can not return it, but it may be simpler to just always return it.) When committing the "oldest" snapshot (immediately above the base) we will update the metadata accordingly. When cloning a volume, this field will be updated in the new volume's metadata. The Cinder "manage volume" operation also needs to allow the user to input the format explicitly for a volume being imported. (TBD: where is this process and checked? Some drivers require it as a metadata kwarg or fail the operation?) Alternatives ------------ Indeed, glusterfs driver has used "qemu-img info" command to judge the format of volume. However, this auto-detection method has many possible error / exploit vectors. Because if the beginning content of a "raw" volume happens to a "qcow2" disk, auto detection method will judge this volume to be a "qcow2" volume wrongly. This has been made safe from the point of view of leaking data, but still does not behave robustly enough. Consider adding metadata representing each file in the snapshot chain's filename and format rather than just that of the base file. This would allow for additional volume/snapshot file validation but is not strictly required for functionality here. Data model impact ----------------- For volumes on filesystem-based drivers, there will be a related record in volume_admin_metadata table. For this record, the key column is "format" and the value is the volume's format in volume_admin_metadata table. REST API impact --------------- The "format" info will returned within "metadata" in volume show API:: /v1/{tenant_id}/volumes/{volume_id} /v2/{tenant_id}/volumes/{volume_id} { "volume": { "status": "available", "metadata": { "format": "raw", } } } The snapshot_actions update_snapshot_status API will recieve format updates from Nova when snapshots are deleted by Nova. This is done by adding a "file_format" field to this API call, i.e.:: { "id": snapshot-id, "status": "available", "progress": "90%", "file_format": { "volume-1234": "raw", "volume-1234.snapshot1": "qcow2" } } Security impact --------------- Implements the proper/complete fix for bug 1350504. Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- Additional arguments likely required for "cinder manage" with these drivers. Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- Fixes problem where a user can cause a volume to become inoperable by writing a qcow2 header into it. (No longer a security issue, but not good.) Developer impact ---------------- It would be ideal to implement this before adding snapshots to the NFS driver. This requires changes in Nova as well. This should enable a later effort to support backup of qcow2 volumes. The volume manage operation must also have the ability to specify the format of an incoming volume file. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: eharney or zhangleiqiang? Work Items ---------- To support this feature, the work items are: * Process additional file_format field in update_snapshot_status API. * Update Nova to send file_format field to update_snapshot_status API. * Return "format" info within "admin_metadata" key in create_volume method of remotefs driver, then the driver can store the format info into db * Add "format" info within "data" key in return value of method cinder.volume.manager.VolumeManager:initialize_connection * Set "format" as visible admin metadata in show API (v1 and v2) and return "format" info within "metadata" in its response body * Update the dest volume's "format" info after migrating the volume. It is a temporary method, and will be removed and fixed as a bug after introducing qemu-nbd support for qcow2 in blueprint [1] Dependencies ============ Nova's libvirt driver will need changes to determine the volume format after a snapshot operation is done. Recent libvirt releases have the ability to list the files in a volume's snapshot tree and the format of each file. This can be used by Nova to determine the required information. Heuristics about expected snapshot behavior can be used if required for prior versions of libvirt. (i.e. blockCommit does not change base format, blockRebase will change base format if the base file and snapshot file have different formats.) (TODO: move libvirt details etc. to Nova spec. Most of these details are not relevant for the volume service.) Testing ======= None Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== [1] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/support-volume-backup-for-qcow2

commit_message:
WIP: Add QoS to NFS driver

Currently the NFS driver does not support QoS. This spec proposes
adding QoS functionality to the NFS driver and will give an
outline of how it can possibly be achieved.

Change-Id: Ia6b23cd68b1ca3e0d9152edb7325a14ac39f7ffd
Implements: blueprint add-qos-to-nfs
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder-specs refs/changes/56/361456/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Add QoS functionality to NFS driver ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/add-qos-to-nfs Problem description =================== Currently the NFS driver does not support QoS, where it is not able control the throughputs of data and not able to monitor the IOPS of a storage object. This is an issue for situations where multiple volumes created with the NFS driver are in a limited pool of space. This spec provides a broad look at what work needs to be done. Use Cases ========= Give deployers the ability to reliably cap volumes given to customers. Allow users to control throughput limits. Prevent workloads from impacting performance of customers. Proposed change =============== This spec proposes adding the above mentioned features by expanding on nfs.py. Specifically new functions will be created that will use the qos_spec associated with the volume_type in order to capture key info, such as max_iops and min_iops which could be use to contrain users in a specifc volume_type tier. We would use the information provided by the qos_spec with the functions in image_utils in order to use qemu-img functions in order to further help the NFS driver provide quality QoS. Alternatives ------------ 1. One obvious alternative is that we can leave NFS how it is and not add Qos functionality to the NFS driver. 2. Another option is that we could use a combination of VLANing and network QoS to try and create a QoS solution. This would lead to a realistic, per volume, QoS solution. 3. Another possibility is that we could create a new share per volume to achieve QoS. However this would not be desirable as it would require creation and maintenance of many NFS shares. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ Adding QoS should improve the performance of customer's volume and prevent any issues with any one client taking more or less than what they are allowed. Other deployer impact --------------------- No known nfs/QoS config options will be added Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: jgregor Work Items ---------- At this point I am still figuring out all the work that will be involved with adding this feature. However, it will take multiple patches in order to get this feature fully implemented. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit tests will need to be added. Also there may be some tempest tests that will need to be added to cover this new functionality. Documentation Impact ==================== NFS documentation will need to be added describing this functionality. Additional document changes could be needed. References ========== https://review.openstack.org/#/c/278430/

commit_message:
Trivial code cleanups

Cleaning up comments and logging to make sure they properly adhere
to Openstack standards.

* Consistently use """ instead of ''' for comments.
* Always lazy-load logging parameters.
* Fixed bad log line in cert_manager.

Change-Id: I547f5dfa61609a899aef9b1470be8d8a6d8e4b81

subject: dhcp: serializing port delete and network rpc calls
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-09-27 01:23:03.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/agent/dhcp/agent.py', 'neutron/api/rpc/agentnotifiers/dhcp_rpc_agent_api.py', 'neutron/tests/unit/agent/dhcp/test_agent.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/4ca8baf6966657eff474bf88e1bd8c296e630a1e', 'message': 'dhcp: serializing port delete and network rpc calls

The port delete events are not synchronized with network rpc events.  This
creates a condition which makes it possible for a port delete event to be
processed just before a previously started network query completes.

The problematic order of operations is as follows:

  1) a network is scheduled to an agent; a network rpc is sent to the
     agent

  2) the agent queries the network data from the server

  3) while that query is in progress a port on that network is deleted; a
     port rpc is sent to the agent

  4) that port delete rpc is received before the network query rpc
     completes

  5) the port delete results in no action because the port was not present
     on the agent

  6) the network query finishes and adds the port to the cache (even
     though the port has already been deleted)

  7) some time passes and a new port is configured with the same IP
     address as the port that was deleted in (3)

  8) the dhcp host file is corrupted with 2 entries for the same IP
     address.

  9) dhcp queries for the newest port is rejected because of the duplicate
     entry in the dhcp host file.

The solution is to add the network_id to the port_delete_end rpc event
so that the _net_lock(network_id) synchronization point can be acquired
so that it is processed serially with other network related events.

To ensure backwards compatibility with newer agents running against older
servers the determination of which network_id value to use in the lock is
handled using a utility that will fallback to the previous mode of operation
whenever the network_id attribute is not present in the *_delete_end RPC
events.  That utility can be removed in the future when it is guaranteed
that the network_id attribute will be present in RPC messages from the
server.

Closes-Bug: #1732456

Change-Id: I735f8b1c9248b12e5feb6cbe970cf67f321e6ebc
Signed-off-by: Allain Legacy <allain.legacy@windriver.com>
(cherry picked from commit fa78b580105111b1238e5b18d415b08e8fb35d97)
'}]
commit_message:
dhcp: serializing port delete and network rpc calls

The port delete events are not synchronized with network rpc events.  This
creates a condition which makes it possible for a port delete event to be
processed just before a previously started network query completes.

The problematic order of operations is as follows:

  1) a network is scheduled to an agent; a network rpc is sent to the
     agent

  2) the agent queries the network data from the server

  3) while that query is in progress a port on that network is deleted; a
     port rpc is sent to the agent

  4) that port delete rpc is received before the network query rpc
     completes

  5) the port delete results in no action because the port was not present
     on the agent

  6) the network query finishes and adds the port to the cache (even
     though the port has already been deleted)

  7) some time passes and a new port is configured with the same IP
     address as the port that was deleted in (3)

  8) the dhcp host file is corrupted with 2 entries for the same IP
     address.

  9) dhcp queries for the newest port is rejected because of the duplicate
     entry in the dhcp host file.

The solution is to add the network_id to the port_delete_end rpc event
so that the _net_lock(network_id) synchronization point can be acquired
so that it is processed serially with other network related events.

To ensure backwards compatibility with newer agents running against older
servers the determination of which network_id value to use in the lock is
handled using a utility that will fallback to the previous mode of operation
whenever the network_id attribute is not present in the *_delete_end RPC
events.  That utility can be removed in the future when it is guaranteed
that the network_id attribute will be present in RPC messages from the
server.

Closes-Bug: #1732456

Change-Id: I735f8b1c9248b12e5feb6cbe970cf67f321e6ebc
Signed-off-by: Allain Legacy <allain.legacy@windriver.com>
(cherry picked from commit fa78b580105111b1238e5b18d415b08e8fb35d97)

commit_message:
Fix random_mac_generator to make proper EUI64s

The initial implementation of random_mac_generator created MAC addresses
that were one octet too long - the MAC addresses would have seven octets
instead of the proper EUI64-standard six.

This resolved testing issues in the consuming patch in Neutron (see
the change referenced in the Needed-By line).  A test is added that
replicates the conditions of the failure.  In the failed tests, the base
mac '12:34:56:78' was instead parsed so it became '12:34:56:7:8'; when
the code went to add 2 octets to the result, there were too many octets
to form a valid EUI64 MAC address.

Implements: blueprint speed-up-neutron-bulk-creation
Needed-By: https://review.openstack.org/584061
Change-Id: I9a2c40709db9204c7686500deac9ee8e8471b1bc

commit_message:
Set rbd_cluster_name to cope with custom cluster names

Cinder requires the Ceph cluster name to be set explicitly in
rbd_cluster_name when not 'ceph'.

Change-Id: I880184255a1f7c39ae66bd8ad7c361d65d378a0c
Closes-Bug: 1796096
(cherry picked from commit 612279161ba26ac02791e20a6eb5aa22e8ac673a)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-cinder refs/changes/12/613212/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add prometheus-monitoring namespace

When using 'prometheus_monitoring=true' in the label option,
'kube-enable-monitoring.service' in the master node has stuck in
'Wait for Grafana pod and then inject data source'.
It caused the 'prometheus-monitoring' namespace doesn't exist,
so scripts don't create pods about Prometheus and Grafana.

To fix the error, I added codes in 'magnum/drivers/common/templates/
kubernetes/fragments/enable-prometheus-monitoring.sh' to make
'prometheus-monitoring' namespace.

We could put codes in a new file like 'magnum/magnum/drivers/
k8s_coreos_v1/templates/fragments/create-kube-namespace.yaml',
but I think it's ok.

commit_message:
Disable tempest run on tripleo-ci-fedora-28-standalone

* Since tripleo-ci-fedora-28-standalone is not yet ready to support
  tempest and python3, till then let's disable tempest run on it.
  Once it is available we can enable tempest here.

Change-Id: If6047b5f19198789a07bb4b2e1dc16111355bf9c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ci refs/changes/45/613545/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: featureset_override: run_tempest: false

commit_message:
podman: stop the docker container during upgrade

When deploying Podman containers, we want to make sure the container
that was running in Docker has been stopped.
That's part of the upgrade process, where later, we'll remove the
container in THT / upgrade_tasks.

Change-Id: I6831b4b952c95fde31febf8e14cb27cf22ff859b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/paunch refs/changes/19/608319/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # When upgrading from Docker to Podman, we want to remove the # container that runs under Docker first before starting it with # Podman. If the container doesn't exist, we suppose it was removed # before and won't fail. if self.runner.cont_cmd == 'podman': try: self.runner.remove_container(container, 'docker') except Exception as e: LOG.debug('Error when running %s docker rm, ' '%s container probably does not exist in Docker ' 'anymore' % (e, container))

commit_message:
Refreshing the repository

This commit aims at updating this repo, as it is intended to be used much more
from now on.

The README and spec template have been updated in order to remove any
comments or informations about launchpad/blueprints.

Change-Id: Ideaf51be8acf5e39713c8c4fa4d186c76c2ec569
Story: 2004180
Task: 27667

Reviews of the specs are done in gerrit, using a similar workflow to how we review and merge changes to the code itself.status of a blueprint for a given release can be found by looking at the blueprint in launchpad. Not all approved blueprints will get fully implemented. Specifications have to be re-proposed for every release. The review may bePrior to the Ocata development cycle, this repository was not used for spec reviews. Reviews prior to Ocata were completed entirely through Launchpad blueprints:: http://blueprints.launchpad.net/cloudkitty Please note, Launchpad blueprints are still used for tracking the current status of blueprints. For more information, see:: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Blueprints

subject: Fix IHA with the new region_name key

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-10-25 10:12:05.000000000', 'files': ['extraconfig/tasks/instanceha/check-run-nova-compute'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/aab90490b705463004b8cfe644af934fff76da21', 'message': 'Fix IHA with the new region_name key

ia change f2e72352b1376ce719614e9cad4e4c71a3f9c3d8 we did the following
in nova-base.yaml:
- nova::placement::os_region_name: {get_param: KeystoneRegion}
+ nova::placement::region_name: {get_param: KeystoneRegion}

But in the IHA script we looked for the os_region_name config key in the
placemenet ini section of nova.conf, which is now missing.
We need to adapt that script as well. Without this fix we'll error
out like this:
Oct 16 09:08:12 overcloud-novacomputeiha-0 dockerd-current[14673]:   File "/var/lib/nova/instanceha/check-run-nova-compute", line 147, in create_nova_connection
Oct 16 09:08:12 overcloud-novacomputeiha-0 dockerd-current[14673]:     region_name=options["os_region_name"][0],
Oct 16 09:08:12 overcloud-novacomputeiha-0 dockerd-current[14673]: KeyError: 'os_region_name'

Closes-Bug: #1798560

Change-Id: I8906145955ab6c444efdfa73beca073a62c26e26
(cherry picked from commit 9235e30c0819d1283a55029f73b4d40fbe6625fe)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix IHA with the new region_name key

ia change f2e72352b1376ce719614e9cad4e4c71a3f9c3d8 we did the following
in nova-base.yaml:
- nova::placement::os_region_name: {get_param: KeystoneRegion}
+ nova::placement::region_name: {get_param: KeystoneRegion}

But in the IHA script we looked for the os_region_name config key in the
placemenet ini section of nova.conf, which is now missing.
We need to adapt that script as well. Without this fix we'll error
out like this:
Oct 16 09:08:12 overcloud-novacomputeiha-0 dockerd-current[14673]:   File "/var/lib/nova/instanceha/check-run-nova-compute", line 147, in create_nova_connection
Oct 16 09:08:12 overcloud-novacomputeiha-0 dockerd-current[14673]:     region_name=options["os_region_name"][0],
Oct 16 09:08:12 overcloud-novacomputeiha-0 dockerd-current[14673]: KeyError: 'os_region_name'

Closes-Bug: #1798560

Change-Id: I8906145955ab6c444efdfa73beca073a62c26e26
(cherry picked from commit 9235e30c0819d1283a55029f73b4d40fbe6625fe)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/58/613258/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if 'region_name' in options: region = options['region_name'][0] elif 'os_region_name' in options: region = options['os_region_name'][0] else: # We actually try to make a client call even with an empty region region = None region_name=region, region_name=region,

commit_message:
bug fix: fix 2 bugs for image client

1. missing glance config section

2. missing import keystoneauth1.exceptions
When call glance fail during download image, it will report:
 NameError: global name 'ks_exc' is not defined

Change-Id: I17f25368f3361b4fc20a0eda9d6b2788beaa6362

commit_message:
Remove autopep8 and formencode from test-requirements.txt

It looks these dependencies are listed in test requirements but not
used in the code. In addition, they are not included in the openstack
global requirement so this commit removes them from the list.

Change-Id: I61c20979b3bbf9b87a5b7285d11efff6b6e3f923

commit_message:
Update lxc_hosts role SHA for apt failures

The 'apt-get upgrade' does not set confdef and
confold currently, so an upgrade which requires
user input can break the cache build[1].

This patch updates the lxc_hosts role SHA to include
Ic6689387a28539b7eb341d55a9db08f078e8e975

[1] http://paste.openstack.org/raw/733076/

Change-Id: I7a50a64a4759865bceccc6ae02132663c328172b

commit_message:
Decoupling number of API and RPC workers for neutron-api

On certain Neutron backends such as OVN where no agents are used,
it's unnecessary to have (so many)RPC workers running. This patch is
decoupling the number of API and RPC workers for neutron server.

In the case that the new NeutronRpcWorkers parameter is not defined,
it'll take the value of NeutronWorkers so that we don't introduce
any regression if some environments don't define it.

Change-Id: I0a3b78947fdeda638d0756f08b577d4351f371e0
Partial-Bug: #1786952
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/79/591679/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- features: - | Now it's possible to define the number of API and RPC workers separately for neutron-api service. This is good for certain network backends such as OVN that don't require RPC communication.

commit_message:
Set the number of RPC workers to 1 for non SRIOV OVN setups

OVN based backend setups don't need RPC communications as they
don't deploy Neutron agents (except for the SRIOV case).

For this reason and to minimize the resources used, this patch
is setting the number of RPC workers to the minimum, which is 1.

Change-Id: Icf84516f24873717cb7615233d2e6341414abfc7
Closes-Bug: #1786952
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>

commit_message:
fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: I3639551e0e8d0b05c7d76158b91771294d66a2c9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/watcher-tempest-plugin refs/changes/98/575098/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: basepython = python3basepython = python3basepython = python3basepython = python3basepython = python3basepython = python3

commit_message:
remove set_host_offline

change_node_power_state action can be used to make a host offline.
set_host_offline never be used and the Nova os-hosts API is deprecated.
So remove it
https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/?expanded=update-host-status-detail#hosts-os-hosts-deprecated

Change-Id: I5f81fc9e2189db39b143d2935540d637bd2d88cc

subject: Add functional regression test for bug 1794996
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-09-28 15:00:45.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/7e101b11f2e059a1fec9e031ed98c3be99b3ae46', 'message': "Add functional regression test for bug 1794996

The _destroy_evacuated_instances method on compute
startup tries to cleanup allocations held against
that compute node resource provider by evacuated
instances, but doesn't take into account that those
evacuated instances could have been deleted in the
meantime which leads to a lazy-load InstanceNotFound
error that kills the startup of the service.

This change adds a functional regression test to recreate
the bug. A subsequent change with the fix will update
the test to show the bug is fixed.

Change-Id: I19b0d8baea5440f5d5bc49a6956d9a97bf031a05
Related-Bug: #1794996

commit_message:
Add functional regression test for bug 1794996

The _destroy_evacuated_instances method on compute
startup tries to cleanup guests from the hypervisor
and allocations held against that compute node resource
provider by evacuated instances, but doesn't take into
account that those evacuated instances could have been
deleted in the meantime which leads to a lazy-load
InstanceNotFound error that kills the startup of the
compute service.

This change adds a functional regression test to recreate
the bug. A subsequent change with the fix will update
the test to show the bug is fixed.

Note that assertFlavorMatchesAllocation and
_boot_and_check_allocations are redefined in the test
class because If6aa37d9b6b48791e070799ab026c816fda4441c
refactored those methods which will cause problems with
backports of this test. The redefined methods will be
removed in a follow up cleanup patch.

Change-Id: I19b0d8baea5440f5d5bc49a6956d9a97bf031a05
Related-Bug: #1794996
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/06/606106/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from nova import exception from nova.tests.functional import integrated_helpers from nova.tests.unit import fake_notifier class TestEvacuateDeleteServerRestartOriginalCompute( integrated_helpers.ProviderUsageBaseTestCase): compute_driver = 'fake.SmallFakeDriver' def setUp(self): super(TestEvacuateDeleteServerRestartOriginalCompute, self).setUp() # Notifications are used in _delete_and_check_allocations. # TODO(mriedem): fake_notifier stubbing should probably live in the # parent class. fake_notifier.stub_notifier(self) self.addCleanup(fake_notifier.reset) self.compute1 = self._start_compute(host='host1') self.compute2 = self._start_compute(host='host2') flavors = self.api.get_flavors() self.flavor1 = flavors[0] def test_evacuate_delete_server_restart_original_compute(self): """Regression test for bug 1794996 where a server is successfully evacuated from a down host and then deleted. Then the source compute host is brought back online and attempts to cleanup allocations for the evacuated (and now deleted) instance. Before the bug is fixed, the original compute fails to start because lazy-loading the instance.flavor on the deleted instance, which is needed to cleanup allocations from the source host, raises InstanceNotFound. """ source_hostname = self.compute1.host dest_hostname = self.compute2.host server = self._boot_and_check_allocations( self.flavor1, source_hostname) source_compute_id = self.admin_api.get_services( host=source_hostname, binary='nova-compute')[0]['id'] self.compute1.stop() # force it down to avoid waiting for the service group to time out self.admin_api.put_service( source_compute_id, {'forced_down': 'true'}) # evacuate the server post = {'evacuate': {}} self.api.post_server_action( server['id'], post) expected_params = {'OS-EXT-SRV-ATTR:host': dest_hostname, 'status': 'ACTIVE'} server = self._wait_for_server_parameter(self.api, server, expected_params) # Expect to have allocation and usages on both computes as the # source compute is still down source_rp_uuid = self._get_provider_uuid_by_host(source_hostname) dest_rp_uuid = self._get_provider_uuid_by_host(dest_hostname) source_usages = self._get_provider_usages(source_rp_uuid) self.assertFlavorMatchesAllocation(self.flavor1, source_usages) dest_usages = self._get_provider_usages(dest_rp_uuid) self.assertFlavorMatchesAllocation(self.flavor1, dest_usages) allocations = self._get_allocations_by_server_uuid(server['id']) self.assertEqual(2, len(allocations)) source_allocation = allocations[source_rp_uuid]['resources'] self.assertFlavorMatchesAllocation(self.flavor1, source_allocation) dest_allocation = allocations[dest_rp_uuid]['resources'] self.assertFlavorMatchesAllocation(self.flavor1, dest_allocation) # Delete the evacuated server. The allocations should be gone from # both the original evacuated-from host and the evacuated-to host. self._delete_and_check_allocations(server) # restart the source compute # FIXME(mriedem): This is bug 1794996 where we try to lazy-load the # instance.flavor from the deleted instance which causes the compute # startup to fail. self.assertRaises(exception.InstanceNotFound, self.restart_compute_service, self.compute1)

commit_message:
Add volume-backed evacuate test

This adds a volume-backed instance evacuate scenario
to the test_evacuate post-test script.

Change-Id: I37120d9ce02de6dadbd279de195d2f289c891123
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/97/604397/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Delete the server and then create a new volume-backed server so we can test # volume-backed evacuate. openstack server delete evacuate-test # TODO(mriedem): Use OSC when it supports boot from volume where nova creates # the root volume from an image. nova boot --flavor ${flavor} --poll \ --block-device id=${image},source=image,dest=volume,size=1,bootindex=0,shutdown=remove \ evacuate-bfv-test nova evacuate evacuate-bfv-test # Wait for the instance to go into ACTIVE state from the evacuate. # TODO(mriedem): Move the polling loops into a common function. count=0 status=$(openstack server show evacuate-bfv-test -f value -c status) while [ "${status}" != "ACTIVE" ] do sleep 1 count=$((count+1)) if [ ${count} -eq 30 ]; then echo "Timed out waiting for server to go to ACTIVE status" exit 6 fi status=$(openstack server show evacuate-bfv-test -f value -c status) done

commit_message:
Add post-test hook for testing evacuate

This adds a post-test bash script to test evacuate
in a multinode job.

This performs two tests:

1. A negative test where we inject a fault by stopping
   libvirt prior to the evacuation and wait for the
   server to go to ERROR status.

2. A positive where we restart libvirt, wait for the
   compute service to be enabled and then evacuate
   the server and wait for it to be ACTIVE.

For now we hack this into the nova-live-migration
job, but it should probably live in a different job
long-term.

Change-Id: I9b7c9ad6b0ab167ba4583681efbbce4b18941178
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/74/602174/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/bash -x BASE=${BASE:-/opt/stack} # Setup auth. source ${BASE}/new/devstack/functions-common # TODO(mriedem): Die if not using libvirt? echo "Using virt driver: ${VIRT_DRIVER}" echo "Ensure we have at least two compute nodes" nodenames=$(openstack hypervisor list -f value -c 'Hypervisor Hostname') node_count=$(echo ${nodenames} | wc -l) if [[ ${node_count} -lt 2 ]]; then echo "Evacuate requires at least two nodes" exit 1 fi echo "Finding the subnode" subnode = '' # TODO(mriedem): If this is flaky, use virsh hostname? local_hostname=$(hostname -s) for nodename in ${nodenames}; do if [[ ${local_hostname} != ${nodename} ]]; then subnode=${nodename} break fi done # Sanity check that we found the subnode. if [[ -z ${subnode} ]]; then echo "Failed to find subnode from nodes: ${nodenames}" exit 2 fi echo "Creating test server on subnode" image=$(openstack image list -f value -c Name | awk 'NR==1{print $1}') flavor=$(openstack flavor list -f value -c Name | awk 'NR==1{print $1}') openstack server create --image ${image} --flavor ${flavor} \ --availability-zone nova:${subnode} --wait evacuate-test echo "Forcing down the subnode so we can evacuate from it" openstack --os-compute-api-version 2.11 compute service set --down ${subnode} nova-compute echo "Killing libvirtd on the localhost before evacuating to trigger failure" libvirtd_pid=$(ps axjf | grep libvirtd | awk 'NR==1{print $1}') kill -9 ${libvirtd_pid} # Now force the evacuation to *this* host; we have to force to bypass the # scheduler since we killed libvirtd which will trigger the libvirt compute # driver to auto-disable the nova-compute service and then the ComputeFilter # would filter out this host and we'd get NoValidHost. Normally forcing a host # during evacuate and bypassing the scheduler is a very bad idea, but we're # doing a negative test here. # TODO(mriedem): Use OSC when it supports evacuate. echo "Forcing evacuate to local host" nova evacuate --force evacuate-test ${local_hostname} # Wait for the instance to go into ERROR state from the failed evacuate. count=0 status=$(openstack server show evacuate-test -f value -c status) while [ ${status} != "ERROR" ] do sleep 1 count=$((count+1)) if [ ${count} -eq 30 ]; then echo "Timed out waiting for server to go to ERROR status" exit 3 fi status=$(openstack server show evacuate-test -f value -c status) done

commit_message:
Add efficacy indicators for workload_stabilization strategy

This patch set adds efficacy indicators for workload_balancing
goal (that includes workload_stabilization and workload_balance
strategies so far).

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-10-23 10:52:21.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/1b3a460b9eda36ef3bd990e02577034f3414e1d3', 'message': "Delete empty karaf directory on host

opendaylight/opt/opendaylight/etc/opendaylight/karaf
from host to /opt/opendaylight/etc/opendaylight/karaf
on container empties the folder on container itself.
Hence on restart/redeploy, ODL can't find files inside
that folder and can't start leading to deployment failure.

Change-Id: I75aabaa2abc0fc9ba789c53f27fc37cfb7769a8b
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2018-10-23 10:55:15.000000000', 'files': ['releasenotes/notes/odl_delete_karaf_folder_on_host-b81465f62fe422d6.yaml', 'docker/services/opendaylight-api.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/9cc52fae4cb58819b3ed42eb9828258871874794', 'message': "Delete empty karaf directory on host

opendaylight/opt/opendaylight/etc/opendaylight/karaf
from host to /opt/opendaylight/etc/opendaylight/karaf
on container empties the folder on container itself.
Hence on restart/redeploy, ODL can't find files inside
that folder and can't start leading to deployment failure.

So delete the empty karaf folder on host so that the contents

commit_message:
Delete empty karaf directory on host

Mounting empty /var/lib/config-data/puppet-generated/
opendaylight/opt/opendaylight/etc/opendaylight/karaf
from host to /opt/opendaylight/etc/opendaylight/karaf
on container empties the folder on container itself.
Hence on restart/redeploy, ODL can't find files inside
that folder and can't start leading to deployment failure.

So delete the empty karaf folder on host so that the contents
of karaf folder inside the container is intact durin redeploy.

Change-Id: I75aabaa2abc0fc9ba789c53f27fc37cfb7769a8b
Closes-Bug: #1799395

commit_message:
Fix bad 'retry' role attribute

Until we have change to ansible-python-3 we have the following warning
[WARNING]: Ignoring invalid attribute: retry

But with package from fedora28 ansible-python3 it's stated as an error
ERROR! 'retry' is not a valid attribute for a Task

This try to fix this and maybe other problems, could be related to
ansible.cfg from fedora28.

Story: https://tree.taiga.io/project/tripleo-ci-board/task/285?kanban-status=1447275
Change-Id: I0de43573ee37a08544452d7709308aa46ad35aa3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart refs/changes/37/613537/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: retries: 3

commit_message:
Function to apply workarounds

The workarounds can be either patches posted on review.openstack.org
 or arbitrary shell commands.
Below is an example of a workarounds:

---
pre_undercloud_upgrade_workaround:
  - BZ#xxxxxyz:
     patch: false
     basedir: ''
     id: ''
     command: 'touch /home/stack/pre_workaround_applied'
post_undercloud_deploy_workarounds:
  - BZ#xxxyyzz:
     patch: true
     basedir: '/usr/share/openstack-tripleo-heat-templates/'
     id: 'xxxyyzz'
     command: ''

Change-Id: Id33c6d9c043433b395d4a4905a36820a18604860

commit_message:
Update min tox version to 2.0

The commands used by constraints need at least tox 2.0.  Update to
reflect reality, which should help with local running of constraints
targets

Change-Id: I1a73f218112236d59ee54797e2e7666ceeb15844

commit_message:
Functional: Allow some time for propagating the healthcheck values

This patch is changing the test_metadata_agent_healthcheck to allow
some time (up to 5 seconds) for expected SB config value to be
propagated.

Prior to this patch, it was checked straight away and sometimes it
it didn't match the expected value.

Change-Id: Ia5308cda75571b624f84efa83cffe2acdc04f097
Related-Bug: #1719574
Co-Authored-By: Terry Wilson <twilson@redhat.com>
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-ovn refs/changes/60/612660/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from neutron.common import utils as n_utils def test_metadata_agent_healthcheck(self): class MetadataSBCFGNotFoundException(Exception): pass def _get_metadata_sb_cfg_value(): chassis_row = self.sb_api.db_find( 'Chassis', ('name', '=', self.chassis_name)).execute( check_error=True)[0] try: return int(chassis_row['external_ids'][ ovn_const.OVN_AGENT_METADATA_SB_CFG_KEY]) except KeyError: raise self.MetadataSBCFGNotFoundException def _check_metadata_sb_cfg_value(expected_val): try: return expected_val == _get_metadata_sb_cfg_value() except self.MetadataSBCFGNotFoundException: return False self.assertRaises(self.MetadataSBCFGNotFoundException, _get_metadata_sb_cfg_value()) try: n_utils.wait_until_true(_check_metadata_sb_cfg_value(2), timeout=5) except n_utils.WaitTimeout: self.fail('OVN_AGENT_METADATA_SB_CFG_KEY != 2')
deleted_lines: def test_metadata_agent_healthcheck(self): chassis_row = self.sb_api.db_find( 'Chassis', ('name', '=', self.chassis_name)).execute( check_error=True)[0] self.assertNotIn(ovn_const.OVN_AGENT_METADATA_SB_CFG_KEY, chassis_row['external_ids']) chassis_row = self.sb_api.db_find( 'Chassis', ('name', '=', self.chassis_name)).execute( check_error=True)[0] self.assertEqual(int(chassis_row['external_ids'][ ovn_const.OVN_AGENT_METADATA_SB_CFG_KEY]), 2)

commit_message:
Add solum-status upgrade check command framework

This adds basic framework for solum-status upgrade
check commands. For now it has only "check_placeholder"
check implemented.
Real checks can be added to this tool in the future.

Change-Id: Icd92e2105e99354a8b184d9be086cc97ce4c12fa
Story: 2003657
Task: 26155
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/solum refs/changes/30/613730/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: solum-status = solum.cmd.status:main
